reblog.content:
We’ll learn how to precisely model navigation in the Composable Architecture using an enum to eliminate impossible runtime states at compile time. And we’ll begin to implement the app’s most complex screen and most complex dependency: the record meeting view and the speech client.

👉 https://www.pointfree.co/episodes/ep247-tour-of-the-composable-architecture-1-0-correctness

content: @stevex AFAIK the @ Binding does not update the view when wrapped value changes. It's just a proxy for getting and setting some value. The @ State on the other hand triggers the update. You have @ State in the ContentView, and the whole view (including child views) is updated whenever ModelRoot changes.

content: @simonbs I use Arc app since Moves was discontinued. It's not perfect, but it can import Moves data and automatically export GPX files to your iCloud Drive, so you can migrate to another solution in the future. I haven't found anything better that "just works" and battery usage is OK in my opinion.

content:
If you need to use just a small subset of #Google services in your #iOS or #macOS application, you don't have to embed heavy, closed-source #SDK dependencies in your project.

Google has a well-documented HTTP REST API, which can be easily used from #SwiftLang.

For example, here is my #GoogleDrive #Swift client library that has no extra dependencies and uses URLSession:

https://github.com/darrarski/swift-google-drive-client

#OpenSource #iOSDev #macOSDev

content: @swiftandtips The "1.0.0" is a marketing version, which can be changed every time you release to a wider audience, while "87" is a build number, bumped whenever uploading a build to App Store Connect. Not sure if this is helpful in your case, but when you use Xcode Cloud the build number can be automatically incremented. You can also have a CI script that adds a git tag like "v1.0.0-87" wherever a build is uploaded to ASC.

reblog.content:
This week we implement a few features in the new Standups app, with some nuanced logic around focus and validation.

Luckily the Composable Architecture comes with all the tools necessary to fully test this logic, and it's all thanks to value types!

👉 https://www.pointfree.co/episodes/ep244-tour-of-the-composable-architecture-1-0-standups-part-1

card.title: Episode #244: Tour of the Composable Architecture 1.0: Standups, Part 1
card.description:
We continue our tour of the Composable Architecture 1.0 by rebuilding one of Apple's most
complex sample projects: [Scrumdinger](https://developer.apple.com/tutorials/app-dev-training/getting-started-with-scrumdinger).
We will create our own "Standups" app using the tools of the Composable Architecture.

reblog.content:
Macros are one of the most celebrated new features of Swift, and many of us are excited to adopt them in our projects.

But unfortunately, there seems to be hidden costs and open questions: what does it take to actually ship a library of macros?!

https://forums.swift.org/t/macro-adoption-concerns-around-swiftsyntax/66588

account.note: A video series exploring Swift and functional programming. Hosted by @mbrandonw and @stephencelis.

card.title: Macro Adoption Concerns around SwiftSyntax
card.description: Macros are one of the most celebrated new features of Swift, and many of us are excited to adopt them in our projects. Many members of the core team are also excited to suggest macros as a solution to many problems. We’d love to hit the ground running and adopt macros in our projects, but the decision to adopt them raises some questions, particularly around the dependence on the swift-syntax package.    Introducing SwiftSyntax to a project immediately incurs an additional 20 second debug build c...

content:
Hello! I’ve recently finished a long-term project and I’m available to hire.

I do consulting for teams and individual developers. I help with iOS and macOS app architecture, solving technical problems, creating clean and maintainable code, test-driven development, and more.

I have more than a decade of experience developing apps in Apple's ecosystem, using Swift and Objective-C. I've been working with SwiftUI and UIKit, and most of Apple's frameworks (like CoreData or AVFoundation).
